Which of the following provides the BEST evidence that all elements of a business continuity plan (BCP) are operating effectively?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Full operational test results provide the BEST evidence that all elements of a business continuity plan (BCP) are operating effectively. A full operational test involves simulating an actual disaster or business disruption and fully activating the business continuity plan to ensure that all elements of the plan, including processes, technologies, and personnel, are functioning as intended.

questions.question_text: Spreadsheets are used to calculate project cost estimates. Totals for each cost category are then keyed into the job-costing system. What is the BEST control to ensure that data is accurately entered into the system?

choices.A: Display back of project detail after entry
choices.C: Reasonableness checks for each cost type
choices.B: Reconciliation of total amounts by project
choices.D: Validity checks, preventing entry of character data

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Reconciliation is a comprehensive control that verifies the overall accuracy of the data entry. It ensures that the sum of the individual entries matches the total expected amount, thereby providing a strong assurance of accuracy.

While the other options provide some level of control, they do not offer the same level of comprehensive assurance:

A. Display back of project detail after entry: This control allows users to review entered data but relies on manual verification and may not catch all errors.

C. Reasonableness checks for each cost type: These checks can identify unusual or unexpected values but may not catch all types of data entry errors and do not verify the accuracy of the total amounts.

D. Validity checks, preventing entry of character data: These checks ensure that only numerical data is entered, but they do not verify the correctness or accuracy of the data itself.

In contrast, reconciling total amounts by project (Option B) provides a more comprehensive validation of data accuracy. It ensures that the overall totals entered into the job-costing system match the totals calculated in the spreadsheets, which serves as a robust check on the accuracy of the data as a whole.

Reasonableness checks focus on identifying data that falls outside the expected range for each cost type. This aligns with CISA's emphasis on preventive controls that catch errors at the source, before they are transferred to the job-costing system.

By implementing reasonableness checks, the system can flag entries that seem too high or low compared to historical data or project benchmarks. This prompts the user to review and potentially correct the data before it gets integrated, improving data integrity from the start.

So, while both "Reconciliation of total amounts by project" and "Validity checks, preventing entry of character data" are valuable controls, they serve slightly different purposes:

- "Reconciliation of total amounts by project" focuses on detecting errors and discrepancies after data entry.
- "Validity checks, preventing entry of character data" focuses on preventing incorrect data from being entered in the first place by ensuring the data meets certain criteria.

In practice, a combination of these controls would provide robust data accuracy and integrity assurance.

Reconciliation involves comparing the totals from the spreadsheet calculations with the totals entered into the job-costing system. This helps identify any discrepancies or errors between the two sets of data, ensuring that the data has been accurately transferred and entered. Reconciliation provides an effective way to catch data entry mistakes and maintain the integrity of the financial information in the system.
